primary_analysis.analysis: A repeating functional progression: I–V–vi–iii–IV–I–IV–V. The pattern outlines a sequence of descending fifths typical of the Romanesca pattern.
primary_analysis.reasoning: The progression cycles through the primary triads and their relatives in D major, forming a descending–fifths sequence (Romanesca) that keeps returning to the tonic. The ending IV–V acts as a half cadence setting up the return to I.
primary_analysis.theoretical_basis: Functional harmony using Roman numeral analysis; recognition of the Romanesca sequential pattern.

evidence.description: The Canon's eight‑chord ostinato is I–V–vi–iii–IV–I–IV–V, a Romanesca sequence【974062402216324⟠L341-L352】【974062402216324⟠L353-L356】.
evidence.musical_basis: The ostinato repeats the same harmonic pattern, allowing a clear mapping to Roman numerals.

evidence.description: The final IV–V creates a half cadence before the progression repeats, preparing a return to I【974062402216324⟠L341-L352】.
evidence.musical_basis: A half cadence occurs when a progression ends on V【851998235519754⟠L843-L849】.

alternative_analyses.analysis: Descending–fifths sequence emphasising the circle of fifths rather than traditional tonic–dominant relationships.
alternative_analyses.reasoning: Viewing the canon as a circle‑of‑fifths sequence highlights the pattern of descending fifths without assigning functional labels to each chord.
alternative_analyses.theoretical_basis: Sequence analysis focusing on intervallic repetition.
alternative_analyses.relationship_to_primary: Emphasises the sequential nature of the pattern rather than functional harmony.

evidence.description: The Canon's progression is widely described as a Romanesca or descending‑fifths sequence【974062402216324⟠L353-L356】.
evidence.musical_basis: Recognition of the repeating pattern as a sequence rather than a series of tonic–dominant relationships.

primary_analysis.analysis: Standard 12‑bar blues progression: I–I–I–I | IV–IV–I–I | V–IV–I–V. The pattern cycles through tonic, subdominant and dominant functions, with a turnaround (V–IV–I–V) leading back to the top.
primary_analysis.reasoning: The progression uses only the I, IV and V chords of C major, characteristic of blues. The final V–I constitutes an authentic cadence before the turnaround repeats.
primary_analysis.theoretical_basis: Blues harmony and functional analysis of I, IV, V chords.

evidence.description: The basic 12‑bar blues uses I, IV and V chords in the pattern I–I–I–I / IV–IV–I–I / V–IV–I–V【583027498882443⟠L191-L210】.
evidence.musical_basis: Roman numeral notation in the article shows the exact pattern.

evidence.description: The V–I in the turnaround functions as an authentic cadence【851998235519754⟠L843-L849】.
evidence.musical_basis: An authentic cadence ends with V–I, establishing tonic closure.

alternative_analyses.analysis: Mixolydian blues interpretation where each I, IV and V chord functions as a modal centre, reflecting the mixolydian scales often used in blues improvisation.
alternative_analyses.reasoning: Blues musicians frequently treat each dominant seventh chord as its own modal centre, leading to a mixolydian interpretation.
alternative_analyses.theoretical_basis: Modal analysis focusing on the use of mixolydian scales over dominant chords.
alternative_analyses.relationship_to_primary: Shifts focus from functional relationships to modal centers on each chord.

evidence.description: Blues improvisation often uses mixolydian scales over dominant chords, supporting a modal view.
evidence.musical_basis: Practitioners use mixolydian modes on I, IV and V chords instead of strictly tonal functions.

primary_analysis.analysis: The tune starts with a major ii–V–I–IV progression in Bb major followed by a minor ii–V–i in G minor, illustrating the relative major/minor relationship.
primary_analysis.reasoning: C‑m7 and F7 function as ii and V in Bb major, resolving to the I (Bbmaj7) and moving to the IV (Ebmaj7). The subsequent Am7♭5 and D7 form a ii°–V in G minor, resolving authentically to Gm7 (i). This reflects the progression described in analyses of the song.
primary_analysis.theoretical_basis: Functional tonal harmony with modulation between relative major and minor keys.

evidence.description: Autumn Leaves is built from major and minor ii–V–I progressions with a switch between relative keys【57229094540833⟠L247-L355】.
evidence.musical_basis: The article notes that the tune uses ii–V–I in the relative major and ii–V–i in the relative minor【57229094540833⟠L359-L369】.

evidence.description: The first bar begins on the tonic of G minor then moves to a dominant IV chord; the second bar is a ii–V progression to Eb (IV in Bb) before resolving to a minor ii–V–i【57229094540833⟠L338-L350】.
evidence.musical_basis: This description aligns with the ii–V–I–IV / ii°–V–i pattern used here.

evidence.description: The Am7♭5–D7–Gm7 segment forms a minor authentic cadence (V–i)【851998235519754⟠L843-L849】.
evidence.musical_basis: An authentic cadence occurs when V resolves to I (or i in minor).

alternative_analyses.analysis: Viewed as a G Aeolian modal progression: each chord relates to the G natural minor scale without emphasis on functional hierarchy.
alternative_analyses.reasoning: Treating the chords as belonging to the G Aeolian mode highlights their shared scale without imposing a major/minor tonal framework.
alternative_analyses.theoretical_basis: Modal analysis focusing on characteristic scale degrees.
alternative_analyses.relationship_to_primary: This interpretation emphasises modal colour over functional relationships.

evidence.description: The progression contains chords built on scale degrees of G natural minor (bIII, bVI, bVII), suggesting an Aeolian perspective.
evidence.musical_basis: In G Aeolian, Ebmaj7 (bVI) and F7 (bVII) are diatonic.

primary_analysis.analysis: The first five bars move through vi–ii–V–I–IV in Ab major before modulating via a ii–V–I into C major.
primary_analysis.reasoning: Fm7 (vi), Bb7 (ii), Ebmaj7 (V), Abmaj7 (I) and Dbmaj7 (IV) form a descending‑fifths progression in Ab. Dm7 and G7 create a ii–V that resolves authentically to Cmaj7 (I) in the new key. This matches analyses of the tune's key centres and Roman numeral patterns.
primary_analysis.theoretical_basis: Functional tonal harmony and key modulation through ii–V–I patterns.

evidence.description: The first five bars contain a 6–2–5–1–4 progression in Ab followed by a 2–5–1 progression in C【399858058302335⟠L146-L152】.
evidence.musical_basis: The article explicitly identifies these Roman numerals in the respective keys.

evidence.description: The A' section repeats the pattern transposed to Eb and G, demonstrating the tune's reliance on ii–V–I progressions【399858058302335⟠L154-L160】.
evidence.musical_basis: The concept of descending fifths and ii–V–I sequences is central to the tune【399858058302335⟠L219-L233】.

evidence.description: The G7–Cmaj7 motion forms an authentic cadence in C major【851998235519754⟠L843-L849】.
evidence.musical_basis: V–I in a major key constitutes an authentic cadence.

alternative_analyses.analysis: Viewing the entire eight‑chord segment as a descending circle‑of‑fifths sequence (Fm7–Bb7–Ebmaj7–Abmaj7–Dbmaj7–G7–Cmaj7) without separating key centres.
alternative_analyses.reasoning: By ignoring key boundaries, one can see the chords as part of a single cycle descending by fifths.
alternative_analyses.theoretical_basis: Sequence analysis highlighting the circle‑of‑fifths motion rather than tonal functions.
alternative_analyses.relationship_to_primary: This removes the tonal modulation into C and instead treats the progression as continuous fifths.

evidence.description: The article notes that ignoring key centres, the first eight bars share the numerals 6–2–5–1–4–2–5–1【399858058302335⟠L219-L233】.
evidence.musical_basis: This interpretation aligns with the idea of a continuous descending‑fifths progression.

title: Prelude in E minor, Op. 28 No. 4

primary_analysis.analysis: A rare perfect cadence in the prelude: V7–i (B7–Em) in E minor.
primary_analysis.reasoning: Chopin's prelude is known for delaying resolution. However, the B7–Em motion provides one of the only perfect cadences in the piece.
primary_analysis.theoretical_basis: Functional analysis of minor key cadences.

evidence.description: The analysis notes that the prelude contains only two perfect cadences (B7–Em)【753479173699514⟠L91-L106】.
evidence.musical_basis: An authentic cadence is defined as V–I/i【851998235519754⟠L843-L849】.

evidence.description: Many dominant chords in the piece change quality instead of resolving, prolonging tension【753479173699514⟠L121-L133】.
evidence.musical_basis: This contrast highlights the significance of the rare authentic cadences.

primary_analysis.analysis: Opening bars: tonic C is prolonged via dominant and ii chords, creating a tonic–dominant–predominant–dominant–tonic pattern.
primary_analysis.reasoning: The first four bars are governed by the C major chord, but Bach passes through the dominant (G) and predominant (ii) before returning to C, exemplifying a prolongation of the tonic.
primary_analysis.theoretical_basis: Schenkerian and functional analysis highlighting tonic prolongation.

evidence.description: The opening four bars are governed by the C major chord and the tonic is prolonged via the dominant and a ii chord【948900344973732⟠L110-L117】.
evidence.musical_basis: The analysis explains that I–V–ii–V–I forms the underlying harmonic structure.

evidence.description: The return from G (V) to C (I) constitutes an authentic cadence【851998235519754⟠L843-L849】.
evidence.musical_basis: V–I is defined as an authentic cadence.
